questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. The patient was walking up stairs at work when he suddenly collapsed in the stairwell. The patient describes the pain as “an elephant sitting on my chest” with associated shortness of breath. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and a twenty-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 154/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 99% on room air. Initial examination demonstrates a diaphoretic male in moderate distress clutching the front of his chest. An initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below. Which of the following cardiac vessels most likely requires revascularization?  


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple comorbidities and cardiovascular risk factors presents with classic features of acute coronary syndrome, including exertional chest pressure not relieved with rest. His initial electrocardiogram meets the criteria for ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), with notable elevations in the anterolateral leads of the heart with reciprocal depressions inferiorly. Given these findings, this patient most likely has occlusion of the left anterior descending coronary artery.   

Myocardial infarction is defined by irreversible necrosis of heart muscle secondary to prolonged ischemia. Clinically, this condition most commonly presents with chest pressure or pain radiating to the arm/jaw with associated dyspnea, diaphoresis, and nausea or vomiting. On electrocardiography, a STEMI can be recognized by the presence of ST-elevations in one or more contiguous leads with reciprocal depressions of corresponding leads.  

The three most commonly occluded vessels include the left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD), the right coronary artery (RCA), and the left circumflex coronary artery (LCX). These areas correspond to the anterior, inferior, and lateral anatomic regions of the heart, respectively. In most cases, the posterior descending artery branches from the right coronary artery (right dominant circulation). However, in a subset of cases, the posterior descending artery branches from the left circumflex coronary artery (left dominant circulation) or from the RCA and LCX (codominant circulation).  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Left anterior descending coronary artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Posterior descending coronary artery :
Incorrect: Infarction of the posterior descending coronary artery manifests with ST-depressions in V1-V3 and tall R-waves. A posterior ECG will demonstrate elevations in V7-V9, confirming the diagnosis. 
❌ Right coronary artery :
Incorrect: Infarction of the right coronary artery manifests with ST-elevations of the inferior leads and reciprocal changes in the anterior leads. 
❌ Left circumflex coronary artery:
Incorrect: Infarction of the left circumflex coronary artery manifests with ST elevations or q-waves in lead I or aVL. 
❌ Obtuse marginal artery :
Incorrect: Like infarctions of the left circumflex coronary artery, infarction of the obtuse marginal artery results in a lateral STEMI pattern on ECG–with elevations or q-waves in leads I, aVL, or V5-V6.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after having multiple syncopal episodes at home. Over several hours, the patient endorses intermittent, substernal chest pressure radiating to her right jaw. She was recently admitted to the hospital two weeks ago following an acute myocardial infarction with stent placement. Since discharge, the patient has occasionally forgotten to take her medications. She has a medical history of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. The patient’s medications include metformin, lisinopril, carvedilol, aspirin, and clopidogrel. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 46/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 97/66 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 94% on room air. A screening electrocardiogram is demonstrated below. Which of the following cardiac vessels is most likely implicated in this patient’s disease process?  


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient’s electrocardiogram demonstrates complete heart block–as evidenced by dyssynchrony between p-waves, QRS complexes, and t-waves. Given this pattern of findings, the most likely implicated coronary artery is the right coronary artery, which contains branches that supply the conducting SA and AV nodes of the heart. In addition, the history of a recent myocardial infarction and medication noncompliance is concerning for in-stent thrombosis requiring revascularization.  

When the AV node is damaged secondary to ischemia, the regular conduction pattern of the heart fails, resulting in independent and asynchronous contractions of the atria and ventricles. When this occurs, bradycardia ensues (the ventricles contract independently at an average rate of 40-45 bpm), manifesting with exertional syncope, angina, or shortness of breath.    

In addition to RCA occlusion, distal left coronary artery occlusion–particularly of the anterior interventricular branch of the LCA–can also result in complete heart block, as this artery contributes to the blood supply of the AV bundle.  



Option Analysis

✅ Right coronary artery :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Posterior descending coronary artery :
Incorrect: Infarction of the posterior descending artery manifests with ST-depressions in V1-V3 and tall R-waves. A posterior ECG will demonstrate elevations in V7-V9, confirming the diagnosis. While this artery is most commonly a branch of the RCA, it is not always implicated in SA or AV node dysfunction–especially if it branches from the LCX.  
❌ Left anterior descending coronary artery:
Incorrect: Infarction of the left anterior descending coronary artery manifests with ST-elevations of the anterior and lateral leads.
❌ Left circumflex coronary artery:
Incorrect: Infarction of the left circumflex coronary artery manifests with ST elevations or q-waves in the lead I or aVL. 
❌ Obtuse marginal artery :
Incorrect: Like infarctions of the left circumflex coronary artery, infarction of the obtuse marginal artery results in a lateral STEMI pattern on ECG–with elevations or q-waves in leads I, aVL, or V5-V6.

questions.text: The process of thyroid hormone synthesis in the thyroid gland yields two types of thyroid hormones, triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4). Which of the following is true regarding the differences between these two types?

choices.text: Only T3 bound to thyroxine-binding globulin is the active form of thyroid hormone
T3 binds nuclear receptors with greater affinity than T4
T4 is the highly active form with a half-life of one to two days
Only a tiny amount of T4 will travel unbound in the blood 0.3%
Once inside the cell, T­4 is mainly converted into reverse T3 (rT3) by 5’- deiodinase

questions.solution:
Nearly all of both thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) are carried in blood tightly bound to thyroxine-binding globulin or albumin. T4 is the more abundant compound, constituting 90% of the circulating thyroid hormone. Both molecules bind the same intracellular receptors of target cells, but T3 is 2- to 10-fold more active than T4. The small, unbound (free) fraction (about 0.03% of T4 and 0.3% of T3) is responsible for the biologic activity. Thus, despite the significant difference in total amount, the free fraction of T3 approximates that of T4, and given that T3 is intrinsically more active than T4, most biologic activity is attributed to T3.  The half-life of T3 is one to two days compared to a week for T4. T3 binds nuclear receptors with greater affinity than T4. Both thyroid hormones increase the number and size of mitochondria and stimulate mitochondrial protein synthesis, helping to enhance metabolic activity.  

Option Analysis

❌ Only T3 bound to thyroxine-binding globulin is the active form of thyroid hormone  :
Incorrect: T3 and T4 bound to TBG and other plasma proteins are the biologically inactive form of thyroid hormone.  
✅ T3 binds nuclear receptors with greater affinity than T4  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ T4 is the highly active form with a half-life of one to two days  :
Incorrect: T3 is the highly active form with a half-life of one to two days. T4 is the less active form with a longer half-life of six to eight days.  
❌ Only a tiny amount of T4 will travel unbound in the blood 0.3%  :
Incorrect: Only a small amount of T3 and T4 will travel unbound in the blood–about 0.03% of T4 and 0.3% of T3–and this fraction is biologically active, which means that this is what gets picked up by virtually every cell in the body.  
❌ Once inside the cell, T­4 is mainly converted into reverse T3 (rT3) by 5’- deiodinase  :
Incorrect: Once inside the cell, T­4 is primarily converted into T3 (not reverse T3) by the enzyme 5’- deiodinase. T3 binds to thyroid hormone receptors within the cell’s nucleus, which regulate gene expression. Reverse T3 (rT3) is a metabolically inactive form of thyroid hormone.

questions.text: A study on the development of women’s secondary sexual characteristics is done. It was shown that some changes like pubic and axillary hair development is due to a contribution of a hormone that is produced outside the ovaries. This hormone is most likely produced in which of the following locations?

choices.text: Zona reticularis of the adrenal cortex
Zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex
Zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex

questions.solution:
The adrenal glands are a pair of almond-shaped organs that sit on top of the kidneys. They are divided into a cortex and a medulla where each has different functions.  

The adrenal cortex is divided into 3 main parts, and each part produces unique hormones. The outermost layer of the cortex is called the zona glomerulosa and is the site of the production of aldosterone. Aldosterone production is unique because it is not controlled by adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) but by angiotensin II. The middle layer of the cortex is called zona fasciculata and it is the site of the production of cortisol. This is controlled by the pituitary gland under the influence of ACTH.  
Finally, the innermost layer of the cortex is called the zona reticularis and is responsible for the production of androgens and estrogens in males and females. In females, the androgens produced in the zona reticularis are in fact responsible for the development of certain secondary sexual characteristics like axillary and pubic hair. The zona reticularis is also controlled by the pituitary gland through ACTH.  

Option Analysis

✅ Zona reticularis of the adrenal cortex  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex  :
Incorrect: The zona fasciculata is responsible for the production of cortisol, not androgens.  
❌ Zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex  :
Incorrect: The zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex is responsible for the production of aldosterone.  
❌ The adrenal medulla  :
Incorrect: The adrenal medulla produces epinephrine and norepinephrine, but does not produce androgens or sex hormones.  
❌ The pituitary gland  :
Incorrect: The pituitary gland is not responsible for the direct production of androgens.

questions.text: The human body obtains vitamin D either from the diet or from sun exposure. Which of the following changes will enhance the production of an active form of vitamin D?
questions.solution:
Normally, total blood calcium is between 8.5 to 10 mg/dl. If calcium levels drop, more parathyroid hormone (PTH) is released, which increases bone resorption and releases calcium and phosphate ions into the blood. PTH also acts on the kidneys to increase calcium reabsorption in the loop of Henle, the distal convoluted tubule, and collecting ducts, while blocking phosphate reabsorption in the proximal tubule. Furthermore, in renal cells in the proximal tubule, it increases the synthesis of 1-alpha-hydroxylase which converts calcifediol into active vitamin D. Decreased levels of phosphate can also trigger the increased synthesis of 1-alpha-hydroxylase.  

Active vitamin D is then transported through the blood to various tissues. In the bones, vitamin D stimulates the release of cytokines including RANKL and macrophage colony-stimulating factors. These cytokines help form osteoclasts, which breaks down bone and releases calcium and phosphate into the blood.  

In enterocytes, active vitamin D increases calcium and phosphate absorption by stimulating the synthesis of calbindin D-28K, a calcium-binding protein that helps stimulate calcium absorption. It also increases the synthesis of sodium-phosphate cotransporters in enterocytes.  

In the kidneys, active vitamin D in the principal cells of the distal convoluted tubules stimulates the synthesis of calbindin D-28K, allowing more calcium to be reabsorbed from the urine. Whereas in tubular cells of the proximal convoluted tubules, it causes increased synthesis of sodium-phosphate cotransporters on the apical surface, which increases phosphate reabsorption.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increased 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol   :
Incorrect: Increased 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol feedback inhibits its own production.  
✅ Increased parathyroid hormone  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypercalcemia:
Incorrect: Hypocalcemia (rather than hypercalcemia) enhances the production of 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol by stimulating the release of PTH.
❌ Hyperphosphatemia:
Incorrect: Hypophosphatemia (rather than hypercalcemia) enhances the production of 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol by increasing the synthesis of 1-alpha-hydroxylase.  
❌ Hypernatremia:
Incorrect: Hypernatremia does not regulate active vitamin D production.

questions.text: An experiment is carried out on the adrenal cortex of mice to determine the enzymes involved in the synthesis of adrenocortical hormones. In the experiment, an enzyme called 11-B hydroxylase was inhibited in the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex. Which of the following steps is most likely to be disrupted as a result of this?
questions.solution:
The adrenal cortex is responsible for the production of adrenocortical hormones, which include aldosterone, cortisol, androgens, and estrogens. Although the synthesis of these hormones take different paths in different areas in the adrenal cortex, they all start with a common precursor, which is cholesterol.  

Under the influence of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) produced by the pituitary gland, the adrenal cortex takes cholesterol from the blood. The same hormone mediates the conversion of cholesterol to pregnenolone by the enzyme cholesterol desmolase. Pregnenolone is then taken by the different zones in the adrenal cortex and used to synthesize adrenocortical hormones.  

Zona glomerulosa  
In the zona glomerulosa, pregnenolone is taken and converted into progesterone by the enzyme 3-β hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (3β-HSD). Progesterone is then converted to 11- deoxycorticosterone by the enzyme 21-hydroxylase. This is followed by the conversion of 11- deoxycorticosterone to corticosterone by 11β-hydroxylase enzyme. Finally, corticosterone is converted into aldosterone by the enzyme aldosterone synthase, which is controlled by angiotensin II.  


Zona Fasciculata  
The zona fasciculata takes pregnenolone and progesterone and they are converted into 17-hydroxypregnenolone and 17-hydroxyprogesterone respectively, by the enzyme 17-α hydroxylase. Then the 17-hydroxypregnenolone is converted into 17-hydroxyprogesterone by the enzyme 3β-HSD. 17-hydroxyprogesterone is converted to 11-deoxycortisol by 21-hydroxylase enzyme, which is then converted to cortisol by 11-β hydroxylase enzyme.  


Zona reticularis  
In the zona reticularis, 17-hydroxypregnenolone and 17-hydroxyprogesterone are taken from the zona fasciculata and converted by the enzyme 17,20-lyase into dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and androstenedione respectively. Androstenedione is converted to testosterone by the enzyme 11-β HSD. On the other hand, DHEA can be converted to androstenedione by the enzyme 3β-HSD which is then converted to testosterone, or alternatively can be converted to androstenediol by 11-β HSD and then to testosterone by 3β-HSD.  Finally, testosterone is converted by the enzyme aromatase to estradiol or estrogen.  



Option Analysis

✅ Conversion of 11-deoxycorticosterone to corticosterone.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Conversion of corticosterone to aldosterone  :
Incorrect: The Conversion of corticosterone to aldosterone is metabolized by the enzyme aldosterone synthase, which is stimulated by angiotensin II.  
❌ Conversion of progesterone to 11-deoxycorticosterone  :
Incorrect: The conversion of progesterone to 11-deoxycorticosterone is done by the enzyme 21-β hydroxylase, not 11β-hydroxylase.  
❌ Conversion of 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol   :
Incorrect: Although 11β-hydroxylase is responsible for the conversion of 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol, this step is part of the production of cortisol which takes place in the zona fasciculata, not zona glomerulosa.  
❌ Conversion of progesterone to 17-hydroxyprogesterone  :
Incorrect: The conversion of progesterone to 17-hydroxyprogesterone is mediated by the enzyme 17-a hydroxylase, not 11β-hydroxylase.

questions.text: A group of researchers are studying the functions and regulation of the parathyroid hormone (PTH). Which of the following metabolic changes will have a stimulatory effect on the release of PTH?
questions.solution:
In addition to hypocalcemia, parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion from the parathyroid chief cells is also stimulated by hyperphosphatemia. The increased serum phosphate binds the serum calcium, leading to reduced stimulation of calcium-sensing receptors in the parathyroid gland. This stimulates the release of PTH.  

PTH increases bone resorption and releases calcium and phosphate ions into the blood. It also acts on the kidneys to increase calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, while blocking phosphate reabsorption in the proximal tubule, thereby leading to increased phosphate excretion via the kidneys. Moreover, it increases the synthesis of 1-alpha-hydroxylase which converts calcifediol into calcitriol (active vitamin D), which increases blood calcium (Ca2+) mainly by increasing the uptake of calcium from the intestines.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hyperkalemia:
Incorrect: Hyperkalemia has no direct effect on PTH secretion.  
✅ Hyperphosphatemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypernatremia:
Incorrect: Hypernatremia has no direct effect on PTH secretion.  
❌ Hypercalcemia:
Incorrect: An increase in serum calcium would inhibit the release of PTH from parathyroid glands.  
❌ Hypermagnesemia:
Incorrect: Hypomagnesemia, rather than hypermagnesemia, regulates the release of PTH levels depending on the reduction in serum magnesium levels. Moderate hypomagnesemia promotes the action of PTH on kidneys to improve magnesium reabsorption, whereas severe hypomagnesemia leads to the inhibition of PTH release.

questions.text: A group of investigators are studying the effect of exogenous steroid intake on the hypothalamus-pituitary-adrenal axis in mice. Which of the following changes will be observed in mice who are receiving exogenous cortisol administration?
questions.solution:
Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is a peptide hormone that helps regulate the release of hormones by the adrenal glands. Secretion of ACTH is dependent on the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.The hypothalamus secretes corticotropin releasing hormone, or CRH, into the hypophyseal portal system, which is a network of capillaries linking the hypothalamus to the anterior part of the pituitary gland. In the anterior pituitary the CRH binds to a surface protein of corticotroph cells, and stimulates them to release ACTH. The main action of ACTH involves stimulating adrenocortical cells of the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex to secrete glucocorticoids which has anti-inflammatory effects, increases blood glucose and stimulates fat and protein breakdown. Increased cortisol levels negatively feedback on the hypothalamus and inhibit hypothalamic release of CRH with a subsequent decrease in ACTH secretion. A similar feedback is seen in patients using exogenous steroids.  


Option Analysis

✅  CRH  ACTH  Cortisol  Decrease  Decrease  Increase :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌  CRH  ACTH  Cortisol  No change  Decrease  Decrease :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Exogenous administration of cortisol inhibits the secretion of CRH via negative feedback inhibition, which in turn decreases ACTH secretion from the pituitary. Serum cortisol levels would be elevated.   
❌  CRH  ACTH  Cortisol  No change  No change  Increase :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Exogenous administration of cortisol inhibits the secretion of CRH via negative feedback inhibition, which in turn decreases ACTH secretion from the pituitary.   
❌  CRH  ACTH  Cortisol  Increase  No change  Increase :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Exogenous administration of cortisol inhibits the secretion of CRH via negative feedback inhibition, which in turn decreases ACTH secretion from the pituitary.   
❌  CRH  ACTH  Cortisol  Decrease  Increase  Increase :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Exogenous administration of cortisol inhibits the secretion of CRH via negative feedback inhibition, which in turn decreases ACTH secretion from the pituitary.

questions.text: An experiment is done to determine the physiology of maintaining normal plasma osmolarity. In the experiment, the plasma osmolarity of a subject is raised to 320 mOsm/L. This triggers the release of a hormone from the posterior pituitary that increases the reabsorption of water from urine in the collecting ducts. Which of the following is an additional function of this hormone?

choices.text: Decreased excretion of urea in urine
Increased excretion of urea in urine
Increased excretion of potassium in urine

questions.solution:
Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is one of the major hormones that regulate blood osmolarity and volume. ADH is produced in the hypothalamus, specifically in the neurons found in the supraoptic nuclei and the paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus, and is then stored in vesicles in the neurons. Once stimulated, these neurons release ADH in the posterior pituitary, where it is then secreted into the blood.  

The major stimulus for the release of ADH has increased plasma osmolarity; but, also other signals can stimulate the release of ADH including decreased blood volume and increased circulating angiotensin II. In contrast, decreased plasma osmolarity, increased blood volume and elevated blood pressures all inhibit the release of ADH.  

Once released, ADH acts on two receptors: V1 and V2 receptors. The major effects of ADH are on V2 receptors, which are found in the distal convoluted tubules and the principal cells of the collecting ducts. V2 receptors are G-protein coupled receptors that, when stimulated, cause increased synthesis of aquaporin-2 channels and increased insertion of these channels on the basolateral membrane of the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts. These channels permit water reabsorption from the urine, thereby increasing water reabsorption from urine. Additionally, ADH also increases the reabsorption of urea in the collecting ducts in order to maximize the corticomedullary gradient, and hence increase the water reabsorption.  

On the other hand, ADH actions on the V1 receptors cause vasoconstriction, which helps bring up the blood pressure, and can be seen in hypovolemic states (e.g., dehydration, blood loss).  

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased excretion of urea in urine  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased excretion of urea in urine  :
Incorrect: Antidiuretic hormone increases the reabsorption of urea from the urine, thereby decreasing its excretion in the urine.  
❌ Increased sodium reabsorption  :
Incorrect: Antidiuretic hormone has no effect on sodium reabsorption in the renal tubules.  
❌ Increased excretion of potassium in urine  :
Incorrect: Antidiuretic hormone has no effect on potassium excretion in the renal tubules.  
❌ Increased secretion of renin  :
Incorrect: Antidiuretic hormone does not stimulate the secretion of renin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is diagnosed with primary hypothyroidism. Administering liothyronine (T3) in this patient would result in which of the following hormonal changes?
questions.solution:
The hypothalamus-pituitary-thyroid axis is regulated by negative feedback by the thyroid hormone on the thyrotropin-releasing (TRH) hormone-secreting neurons in the hypothalamus and thyrotrophs of the anterior pituitary. For example, a slight reduction of thyroid hormone triggers a rapid increase of TRH and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) secretion, resulting in thyroid gland stimulation and increased thyroid hormone production. When thyroid hormone reaches a normal level, it feeds back to suppress TRH and TSH, and a new steady state is attained.  

In patients with primary hypothyroidism, TSH should be elevated when T4 and T3 concentrations are low, reflecting reduced feedback inhibition. Treatment with liothyronine (T3) would increase T3 levels and decrease T4 secondary to the suppression of TSH via negative feedback to the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary. Reverse T3 would also be decreased because it is derived from the peripheral conversion of T4.  


Option Analysis

✅ Thyroid-stimulating hormone  T3  T4  Reverse T3   Decrease  Increase  Decrease   Decrease :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌  Thyroid-stimulating hormone  T3  T4  Reverse T3   No Change Increase  Decrease   Increase:
Incorrect: Although treatment with liothyronine (T3) would increase T3 levels, it would suppress TSH via negative feedback to the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary. Reverse T3 would also be decreased because it is derived from the peripheral conversion of T4.   
❌  Thyroid-stimulating hormone  T3  T4  Reverse T3   No Change Increase  Decrease   Decrease :
Incorrect: Although treatment with liothyronine (T3) would increase T3 levels, it would lead to the suppression of TSH via negative feedback to the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary.   
❌  Thyroid-stimulating hormone  T3  T4  Reverse T3   Decrease  Increase  Decrease   Increase :
Incorrect: Although treatment with liothyronine (T3) would increase T3 levels and suppression of TSH via negative feedback to the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary. Reverse T3 would also be decreased because it is derived from the peripheral conversion of T4.   
❌  Thyroid-stimulating hormone  T3  T4  Reverse T3   Decrease  Increase  Increase Decrease :
Incorrect: Treatment with liothyronine (T3) would result in an increased T3 but decreased T4 levels due to negative feedback inhibition of TSH.

questions.text: The human body obtains vitamin D either from the diet or from sun exposure. Which of the following represents the conversion of vitamin D derived from dietary animal sources to its active form in the kidney?
questions.solution:
Vitamin D is a steroid hormone. Active vitamin D starts out as either vitamin D2 (ergocalciferol), which is derived from dietary plant sources, or vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol), which is either derived from dietary animal products but can also be made in skin cells that are exposed to sunlight.  

When vitamin D2 and D3 reach the small intestine, they get packaged along with bile salts into micelles, which get absorbed into the enterocytes. They are then incorporated into chylomicrons, which travel through the lymphatic system to enter the blood. In the blood, they bind vitamin D-binding proteins, which take them to the liver. In the hepatic endoplasmic reticulum, vitamin D2 and D3 are converted to 25-hydroxy ergocalciferol and 25-hydroxycholecalciferol, respectively, by the enzyme 25-hydroxylase. These re enter the blood and travel to the proximal tubules of the kidneys, where the enzyme 1-alpha-hydroxylase converts 25-hydroxy ergocalciferol and 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25-dihydroxy ergocalciferol and 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol, respectively, which are the active forms of vitamin D.  

In the skin, keratinocytes produce 7-dehydrocholesterol, a precursor molecule for cholecalciferol. When the skin is exposed to sunlight, 7-dehydrocholesterol absorbs ultraviolet B radiation and is converted to previtamin D3 via photolysis. Then, heat generated by cellular metabolic activities causes the previtamin D3 molecule to isomerize (change its shape) to form vitamin D3 or cholecalciferol. The vitamin D3 molecules then enter the blood, and follow the same path as dietary cholecalciferol to the liver, and then to the kidneys.  


Option Analysis

❌ Cholecalciferol → 25-hydroxycholecalciferol  :
Incorrect: The conversion of cholecalciferol to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol by 25-hydroxylase takes place in the liver.  
✅ 25-hydroxycholecalciferol → 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ergocalciferol → 25-hydroxyergocalciferol   :
Incorrect: The conversion of ergocalciferol to 25-hydroxyergocalciferol by 25-hydroxylase takes place in the liver. Ergocalciferol is derived from dietary plant sources.  
❌ 7-dehydrocholesterol → cholecalciferol  :
Incorrect: The conversion of 7-dehydrocholesterol to cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) takes place in the skin under the influence of ultraviolet B (UVB) rays.  
❌ 25-hydroxycholecalciferol → 24,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol  :
Incorrect: The deactivation of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 24,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol occurs in the kidneys and is stimulated by high concentrations of 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D is the active form of vitamin D.

questions.text: An essential step in the formation of thyroid hormones is the organification of iodine to form monoiodothyronine (MIT) and di-iodothyronine (DIT). Which of the following molecules is responsible for this reaction?
questions.solution:
Thyroid hormones are triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4 or tetraiodothyronine). T3 and T4 are produced by the thyroid gland follicles, lined with follicular cells and separated by a small amount of connective tissue. The apical side of follicular cells surrounds a central cavity filled with colloids containing thyroglobulin.  

Thyroglobulin is a large glycoprotein synthesized by the follicular cells and then secreted into the follicle's lumen to be stored in the colloid. The basolateral membrane of follicular cells contains a sodium-iodide symporter, which pumps two sodium ions into the cell down their electrochemical gradient. Iodide is pumped into the colloid through an ion transporter called pendrin, which exchanges iodide for chloride. Iodide undergoes oxidation in the colloid with thyroperoxidase, which changes it into an iodine atom. It is then attached to tyrosine amino acid residues. This process is called iodination.  

Tyrosine residues bound by only one iodine yield monoiodotyrosine (MIT), whereas others bound by two iodine atoms yield diiodotyrosine (DIT). These molecules are then linked together by thyroperoxidase. Linking one MIT with one DIT creates T3, while linking two DIT molecules creates T4–both T3 and T4 remain bound to thyroglobulin.  


Option Analysis

❌ Thyroid deiodinase  :
Incorrect: Thyroid deiodinase is responsible for the recycling (deiodination) of MIT and DIT.  
✅ Thyroid peroxidase  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 5'-deiodinase  :
Incorrect: 5′-deiodinase converts T4 (the major thyroid product) to T3 (the more active form of the thyroid hormone) in peripheral tissues.  
❌ Perchlorate:
Incorrect: Perchlorate is a chemical that inhibits iodine from entering follicular cells.  
❌ Propylthiouracil:
Incorrect: Propylthiouracil (PTU) inhibits thyroid peroxidase–mediated iodination of tyrosine residues in thyroglobulin. In addition, it can block the conversion of thyroxine to triiodothyronine within the thyroid and in peripheral tissues. PTU can be used in patients with hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: The total amount of calcium circulating in the serum is either protein-bound, anion-bound, or ionized calcium. Which of the following changes will be seen in a patient with a serum pH of 7.55?
questions.solution:
Plasma calcium concentration is about 5 to 10 mEq/L and it can be found in three forms:  
  • 50% is ionized and is physiologically active  
  • ~40% of plasma calcium is bound to proteins and is physiologically inactive  
  • 10% is bound to anions like phosphate or citrate   

Hypoproteinemia (e.g., nephrotic syndrome, liver cirrhosis, severe malnutrition, malabsorption) results in a total decrease in Ca2+ level, but ionized Ca2+ levels are unaffected. On the other hand, pH influences the binding of calcium to serum proteins.  
- ↑ pH → ↓ H+ in serum binding to proteins → ↑ Ca2+ binding to proteins → ↓ ionized Ca2+ concentration compensatory ↑ PTH  
- ↓ pH → ↑ H+ in serum binding to proteins → ↓ Ca2+ binding to proteins → ↑ ionized Ca2+ concentration compensatory ↓ PTH  

Option Analysis

❌ ↑ ionized Ca2+  :
Incorrect: An increase in pH (more basic) decreases the amount of H+ in serum that binds to proteins, thereby increasing Ca2+ binding to proteins. This leads to a decrease in ionized calcium.  
✅ ↓ ionized Ca2+  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ ↓ PTH  :
Incorrect: An increase in pH (more basic) decreases the amount of H+ in serum that binds to proteins, thereby increasing Ca2+ binding to proteins. This leads to a decrease in ionized calcium, which stimulates the release of parathyroid hormone (PTH).  
❌ ↓ 1-alpha hydroxylase activity  :
Incorrect: An increase in pH (more basic) decreases the amount of H+ in serum that binds to proteins, thereby increasing Ca2+ binding to proteins. This leads to a decrease in ionized calcium, which stimulates the release of parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH enhances the activity of 1-alpha hydroxylase in the proximal convoluted tubule and increases calcium reabsorption.  
❌ ↑ calcitonin  :
Incorrect: An increase in pH (more basic) decreases the amount of H+ in serum that binds to proteins, thereby increasing Ca2+ binding to proteins. This leads to a decrease in ionized calcium. Calcitonin is released in response to high serum ionized calcium (not low).

questions.text: A hormone is studied to determine its effects in the target organ. In the study, the hormone was found to diffuse into the cell and bind its receptor in the cytoplasm which then translocates into the nucleus and binds to the DNA, mediating its effects. Which of the following is the most likely hormone studied?
questions.solution:
Hormones in the body produce their effects by binding to their receptors. These receptors are widely distributed. The major two types of hormones in the body are peptide hormones and steroid hormones, both of which have significant differences.  

Peptide hormones are hydrophilic; therefore, they are unable to cross the cell membrane. Because of that, the receptors are found on the cell surface (transmembrane receptors). These receptors also vary depending on each hormone. Some examples include:  
  • G-protein-coupled receptors: these receptors are coupled with a G protein and mediate their action via a secondary messenger.  
  • Receptor tyrosine kinase: these receptors have an intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity and once activated induce a series of reactions in the cell. Insulin receptor is a tyrosine kinase receptor.  
  • Non-receptor tyrosine kinase receptors: these receptors have no intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity but once activated, they activate a pathway (e.g. JAK-STAT pathway) that activates an intracellular tyrosine kinase.  

On the other hand, steroid hormones (e.g. cortisol, aldosterone, androgens, estrogens) are lipophilic, and therefore they are able to freely cross the cell membrane into the cell. Their receptors are found in the cell. These hormones go into the cell and bind to their receptors in the cytoplasm. Once bound to the hormone, the receptor gets activated and translocates into the nucleus, and binds to the DNA in an enhancer-like location altering gene transcription and causing a cellular response. Besides steroid hormones, thyroid hormone receptors are found inside the cell, as well as vitamin D receptors.

Option Analysis

✅ Cortisol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Growth hormone  :
Incorrect: Growth hormone receptor is a transmembrane receptor, not an intracellular receptor.  
❌ Glucagon:
Incorrect: Glucagon receptors are transmembrane receptors and are not located intracellularly.  
❌ Insulin:
Incorrect: Insulin receptors are transmembrane receptors and are not located intracellularly.  
❌ Calcitonin:
Incorrect: Calcitonin receptors are transmembrane receptors and are not located intracellularly

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying the functions and features of the pancreatic exocrine secretions. They take samples of pancreatic secretions at various stages in test subjects, including 30 minutes after eating a meal, and in subjects who have fasted. Which of the following is true regarding the pancreatic exocrine secretions?

choices.text: The bicarbonate concentration in the pancreatic fluid is higher during high flow rates.
All hormones secreted by pancreatic acinar cells are inactive and activated in the intestines.
The pancreatic fluid is hypotonic compared to plasma
The chloride concentration in the pancreatic fluid is higher during high flow rates
The chloride and bicarbonate concentrations in the pancreatic fluid are higher during high flow rates

questions.solution:
The pancreas is an abdominal organ that has multiple functions. The secretions of the pancreas are divided into endocrine and exocrine secretions.  

The endocrine secretions of the pancreas are secreted from the islets of Langerhans and directly to the blood. This includes the two primary hormones that control blood sugar levels: insulin and glucagon. Additionally, somatostatin is secreted from the islets of Langerhans and has significant inhibitory effects on the secretion of other endocrine hormones.  

The exocrine secretions of the pancreas are major contributors to the digestive process in the intestines. They are produced from the acini of the pancreas and drain into the intestines through the pancreatic duct.  

They are made of acinar cells and ductal cells. Acinar cells produce three major digestive enzymes: amylase, lipase, and proteases. Proteases are produced in an inactive form called zymogens (e.g., trypsinogen) to prevent autodigestion of the pancreas. Once in the intestines, trypsinogen is converted to trypsin by brush border enteropeptidase, and trypsin activates other proteases.  

Ductal cells of the acini are responsible for the production of the pancreatic fluid containing sodium, potassium, chloride, and bicarbonate. The pancreatic fluid is isotonic compared to the plasma because the sodium and potassium concentrations in the fluid are the same as in the plasma and remain constant regardless of the flow rate of the pancreatic fluids. On the other hand, the bicarbonate and chloride concentrations in the pancreatic fluids change with the rate of flow. In states of high flow (e.g. after a meal), the concentration of bicarbonate in the pancreatic fluid increases to help neutralize the acid from the stomach. Since bicarbonate is exchanged with chloride in the fluid, chloride concentration decreases in high flow states.   

Option Analysis

✅ The bicarbonate concentration in the pancreatic fluid is higher during high flow rates.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ All hormones secreted by pancreatic acinar cells are inactive and activated in the intestines.  :
Incorrect: Only proteases are secreted as zymogens (inactive form) and activated in the intestines. Amylase and lipase produced by acinar cells are in the active form.  
❌ The pancreatic fluid is hypotonic compared to plasma  :
Incorrect: The pancreatic fluid is isotonic compared to plasma.  
❌ The chloride concentration in the pancreatic fluid is higher during high flow rates  :
Incorrect: Chloride concentration in the pancreatic fluid is lower during high flow rates.  
❌ The chloride and bicarbonate concentrations in the pancreatic fluid are higher during high flow rates  :
Incorrect: During high flow rates, the bicarbonate concentration is higher while the chloride concentration is lower in pancreatic secretions.

questions.text: A group of researchers are studying the metabolic effects of alcohol use disorder and the associated electrolyte abnormalities. Which of the following combinations is most likely to be present in an individual with severe alcohol use disorder?
questions.solution:
Severe magnesium depletion (usually <1.2 mg/dL), such as that seen with alcohol use disorder, can result in hypocalcemia, which is due to the suppressive effect of hypomagnesemia on parathyroid secretion as well as skeletal resistance to parathyroid hormone (PTH).   

On the contrary, moderate hypomagnesemia promotes the action of PTH on kidneys to improve magnesium reabsorption.  

Option Analysis

❌ Normal magnesium, increase PTH  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Alcohol use disorder would result in severe hypomagnesemia, leading to the inhibition of PTH release.  
❌ Moderate hypomagnesemia, decrease PTH  :
Incorrect: Moderate hypomagnesemia stimulates the release of PTH.  
✅ Severe hypomagnesemia, decrease PTH  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Normal magnesium, normal PTH  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Alcohol use disorder would result in severe hypomagnesemia, leading to the inhibition of PTH release.  
❌ Severe hypomagnesemia, increase PTH  :
Incorrect: Severe hypomagnesemia inhibits the release of PTH.

questions.text: Glucagon, a hormone produced during a period of fasting, is made by pancreatic α-cells, which are adjacent to the insulin-producing β-cells. Which of the following best describes the action of glucagon?

choices.text: Inhibits the activity of glycogen phosphorylase

questions.solution:
Glucagon, a hormone produced during a period of fasting, is made by pancreatic α-cells, which are adjacent to the insulin-producing β-cells. Glucagon signals via Gs-protein coupled receptors and the secondary messenger molecule cyclic AMP. It primarily acts on the liver and adipose tissue in humans. It stimulates processes that promote the release of glucose into the system, such as glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, and fatty acid oxidation. Glucagon levels increase two to threefold in response to hypoglycemia, and the liver begins production of glucose from glycogen. During times of high blood glucose, glucagon is reduced to half of its normal level. Glucagon also stimulates the release of insulin, thereby allowing insulin-sensitive cells to take up the released glucose. Glucagon secretion is also inhibited by insulin, amylin, and somatostatin.   

Option Analysis

❌ Stimulates glycogen synthesis  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Glucagon inhibits glycogen synthesis by the enzyme glycogen synthase.  
❌ Increases the rate of glycolysis  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Glucagon decreases glycolysis.  
❌ Inhibits gluconeogenesis  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Glucagon stimulates gluconeogenesis.  
❌ Inhibits the activity of glycogen phosphorylase  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Glucagon promotes glycogenolysis by stimulating glycogen phosphorylase.  
✅ Stimulates fatty acid oxidation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit at ten weeks gestation. The patient has no active complaints at this time. Vitals are within normal limits. Serum studies in this patient are most likely to show the following sets of laboratory values?
questions.solution:
Thyroglobulin (Tg) plays a vital role in synthesizing and storing thyroid hormones. Under normal circumstances, TBG binds noncovalently to nearly all of the T4 and T3 in plasma, and it binds T4 with greater affinity than T3.  

The hyperestrogenic state during pregnancy stimulates the synthesis of thyroid-binding globulin (TBG) and increases TBG's glycosylation. This process slows the clearance of TBG, increasing its serum level. As more free T3 and T4 bind to TBG, the level of free thyroid hormones decreases. Consequently, the pituitary gland secretes more TSH, enhancing the production and secretion of thyroid hormones. This achieves a new equilibrium in which the total T3 and T4 levels (i.e., bound and unbound T3 and T4) are increased while the free T3 and T4 levels are normal. On the other hand, in states of hypoproteinemia (e.g., nephrotic syndrome, chronic liver disease), TBG synthesis decreases, leading to an increase in free T3/T4 in serum. This reduces thyroid hormone synthesis.   

Option Analysis

✅  Thyroid-binding globulin  Free T3  Free T4  Total T3 + T4  ↑  Normal  Normal  ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Thyroid-binding globulin  Free T3  Free T4  Total T3 + T4 ↓ Normal  Normal  ↓ :
Incorrect: This set of thyroid function tests is typically seen in conditions that cause thyroid-binding globulin deficiency (e.g., nephrotic syndrome, cirrhosis), which leads to a higher level of free T3 and T4. Consequently, TSH secretion is suppressed, and the new equilibrium shows decreased total T3 and T4 levels with normal free T3 and T4 levels.   
❌  Thyroid-binding globulin  Free T3  Free T4  Total T3 + T4  Normal   Normal  Normal  Normal  :
Incorrect: This set of thyroid function tests is typically seen in a healthy nonpregnant individual. However, the hyperestrogenic state in pregnancy results in physiological changes that would alter this patient's thyroid function test.   
❌  Thyroid-binding globulin  Free T3  Free T4  Total T3 + T4  Normal   ↑ ↑ ↑ :
Incorrect: A thyroid function test that shows an increase in the free and total T3 and T4 levels is typically seen in hyperthyroidism. Although hCG, which increases significantly during pregnancy, has a thyrotropic activity, this patient is clinically euthyroid (i.e., normal heart rate and blood pressure and no symptoms of hyperthyroidism).   
❌  Thyroid-binding globulin  Free T3  Free T4  Total T3 + T4  ↓ ↓ Normal  ↓:
Incorrect: A normal free T4 level in decreased thyroid-binding globulin, free T3, and total T3 and T4 levels can be seen in sick euthyroid syndrome. Sick euthyroid syndrome is seen in severely ill patients and is therefore unlikely in this healthy pregnant patient.

questions.text: A group of investigators is studying the function of the thyroid gland. They discovered that the thyroid hormone acts on nearly every cell in the body. Which of the following is most appropriate regarding thyroid hormone?

choices.text: It inhibits ovulation in females by inhibiting GnRH synthesis and release
It has cardiac inotropic and chronotropic effects
It stimulates linear growth and muscle mass through IGF-1
It regulates renal free water reabsorption and serum osmolality
It increases Ca2+ reabsorption from the distal collecting tubule

questions.solution:
Thyroid hormones act on nearly every cell in the body. It is essential for normal growth and development. It controls the rate of metabolism and, therefore, the function of practically every organ in the body. Thyroid hormones help activate the sympathetic nervous system, which is responsible for the fight or flight response. The following are some examples of the specific effects of thyroid hormone.  

  • It has cardiac inotropic and chronotropic effects, increases cardiac output and blood volume, and decreases systemic vascular resistance.  
  • It induces white adipose tissue differentiation, lipogenic enzymes, and intracellular lipid accumulation; stimulates adipocyte cell proliferation; stimulates uncoupling proteins; and uncouples oxidative phosphorylation.  
  • It regulates triglyceride and cholesterol metabolism, as well as lipoprotein homeostasis.
  • It regulates the synthesis of pituitary hormones, stimulates growth hormone production, and inhibits TSH  
  • It is necessary for axonal growth and development  

Option Analysis

❌ It inhibits ovulation in females by inhibiting GnRH synthesis and release  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Prolactin inhibits ovulation in females by inhibiting GnRH synthesis and release.
✅ It has cardiac inotropic and chronotropic effects  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It stimulates linear growth and muscle mass through IGF-1  :
Incorrect: Thyroid hormone is essential for bone growth and development by activating osteoclast and osteoblast activities. It acts synergistically with growth hormone but does not act through IGF-I (the mechanism of growth hormone).  
❌ It regulates renal free water reabsorption and serum osmolality  :
Incorrect: Vasopressin regulates renal free water reabsorption and serum osmolality.  
❌ It increases Ca2+ reabsorption from the distal collecting tubule  :
Incorrect: Parathyroid hormone increases Ca2+ reabsorption from the distal collecting tubule.

questions.text: Parathyroid hormone is released from the parathyroid gland in response to hypocalcemia. Which of the following electrolyte changes will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Increased phosphate reabsorption from the proximal convoluted tubule
Increased calcium reabsorption from the distal convoluted tubule
Increased calcium reabsorption from the proximal convoluted tubule
Increased phosphate reabsorption from the distal convoluted tubule

questions.solution:
A slight decrease in the free ionized Ca2+ level is sensed through the Ca2+ sensor in parathyroid chief cells, resulting in an increased release of parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH binds to receptors in osteoblasts leading to the recruitment of pre-osteoclasts and their maturation to active osteoclasts, which are responsible for increased bone resorption and release of Ca2+ and inorganic phosphate (Pi) into the circulation.  

In the kidney, PTH promotes Ca2+ reabsorption from the distal convoluted tubule and Pi excretion in the urine. In addition, PTH stimulates the hydroxylation of 25-hydroxyvitamin D at the 1-position, leading to the formation of the active form of vitamin D (calcitriol). Vitamin D increases intestinal absorption of dietary Ca2+ and renal reabsorption of filtered Ca2+. In the bone, vitamin D increases the number of osteoclasts and stimulates bone resorption, with a resulting increase in the release of Ca2+ into the circulation. An increase in free ionized Ca2+ levels decreases the release of PTH from the parathyroid gland, decreases the activation of vitamin D in the kidney, and stimulates parafollicular cells of the thyroid gland to release the hormone calcitonin.  

Option Analysis

❌ Decreased calcium resorption from bone  :
Incorrect: PTH increases calcium resorption from the bone to increase serum calcium levels.  
❌ Increased phosphate reabsorption from the proximal convoluted tubule  :
Incorrect: PTH decreases phosphate reabsorption from the proximal convoluted tubule.  
✅ Increased calcium reabsorption from the distal convoluted tubule  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased calcium reabsorption from the proximal convoluted tubule   :
Incorrect: PTH does not affect calcium reabsorption in the proximal tubule.  
❌ Increased phosphate reabsorption from the distal convoluted tubule  :
Incorrect: PTH reduces the reabsorption of phosphate from the proximal tubule of the kidney, which means more phosphate is excreted through the urine (mnemonic: PTH can be remembered as the “phosphate-trashing hormone”)

questions.text: A scientist is studying different types of glucose transporters (GLUT) found in human tissues. Which GLUT proteins depend on insulin for its expression and upregulation on the cell surface?
questions.solution:
Glucose is one of the main energy sources in human tissues. There are seven important types of glucose transporters in the human body, which include glucose transporters 1 through 5 (GLUT 1-5) and sodium-glucose cotransporters (SGLT) 1 and 2 (found in the small intestines and kidneys, respectively).  

For the most part, the expression of these transporters is independent of insulin. However, expression, upregulation, and exocytosis of GLUT4 require insulin. Insulin is an anabolic hormone that increases glycogen, triglyceride, adenosine triphosphate (ATP), and protein synthesis while down-regulating lipolysis and glucagon release.  

GLUT4, an insulin-dependent glucose transporter, is mainly found in adipose tissues and striated muscles. Exercise and insulin increase their expression, which leads to increased intracellular glucose and resultant ATP generation from glucose metabolism.  



Option Analysis

❌ GLUT1:
Incorrect: GLUT1 is found in red blood cells, the brain, the cornea, and placental tissues. It is not dependent on insulin for its expression and upregulation.
❌ GLUT2:
Incorrect: GLUT2 is found in beta islet cells of the pancreas, liver, kidneys, and gastrointestinal tract. This protein is not dependent on insulin for expression and upregulation.
❌ GLUT3:
Incorrect: GLUT3, like GLUT1, is found in the brain and placental tissues. It is not dependent on insulin for its expression and upregulation.
✅ GLUT4:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ GLUT5:
Incorrect: GLUT5 is found in spermatocytes and gastrointestinal tract tissue. It is not dependent on insulin for its expression and upregulation.

questions.text: An investigator is studying weight regulation using experimental mouse models. Knockout mice are created with a homozygous mutation in ghrelin receptors, preventing the receptors from binding to ghrelin and initiating its normal signaling cascade. Which of the following best describes the normal role of ghrelin?

choices.text: Stimulates smooth muscle contraction in the upper gastrointestinal tract
Acts on hypothalamus to decrease appetite
Stimulates appetite and promotes weight gain

questions.solution:
Ghrelin is produced primarily in the stomach in response to fasting. It stimulates appetite and promotes weight gain. Sleep deprivation, fasting, or Prader-Willi syndrome lead to increased ghrelin levels. It acts on the lateral area of the hypothalamus (hunger center) to stimulate appetite.  

On the other hand, leptin, which is primarily produced in adipocytes and large fat cells, decreases food intake in the following ways: 
  •  It decreases the production of neuropeptide Y, a potent appetite stimulant, in the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus. 
  •  It stimulates the production of proopiomelanocortin (POMC) in the arcuate nucleus. Alpha-melanocyte-stimulating hormone is produced by cleavage of POMC and inhibits food intake.  
Mutation of the leptin gene can cause severe obesity. Sleep deprivation or starvation decreases leptin production. Leptin typically acts on the ventromedial area of the hypothalamus (satiety center) to suppress appetite.  



Option Analysis

❌ Stimulation of gallbladder contraction:
Incorrect: Cholecystokinin stimulates gallbladder contraction and release of pancreatic enzymes and bicarbonate secretion.
❌ Stimulates parietal cell acid production:
Incorrect: Gastrin stimulates parietal cell acid production by G cells in the gastric antrum in response to vagal activity and gastric distention.  
❌ Stimulates smooth muscle contraction in the upper gastrointestinal tract:
Incorrect: Motilin stimulates smooth muscle contraction in the upper gastrointestinal tract and generally increases gastric motility.  
❌ Acts on hypothalamus to decrease appetite  :
Incorrect: Leptin is produced by fat cells in response to short-term food intake and long-term adequacy of fat stores. It acts on the hypothalamus to decrease appetite. During fasting states, leptin levels fall.  
✅ Stimulates appetite and promotes weight gain:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A group of investigators are studying the hypothalamic-pituitary axis involved in the release of prolactin. Which of the following is true regarding the regulation of prolactin release?

choices.text: Prolactin secretion from the posterior pituitary is constantly inhibited by dopamine
Metoclopramide inhibits the release of prolactin
Thyrotropin-releasing hormone can stimulate prolactin release
Prolactin release from the anterior pituitary stimulates GnRH
Prolactin stimulates its own release by increasing dopamine synthesis

questions.solution:
Prolactin is secreted by the lactotroph cells in the anterior pituitary gland. In women that are not pregnant or breastfeeding, and in men, prolactin levels are usually kept in check by the hypothalamus in two ways. First, its secretion is tonically inhibited by dopamine from the tuberoinfundibular pathway of the hypothalamus. Additionally, increased prolactin in turn inhibits its own secretion by increasing dopamine synthesis and secretion from the hypothalamus. It is important to note that thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) increases prolactin secretion, and therefore, the elevation of TRH (such as in 1° or 2° hypothyroidism) can result in hyperprolactinemia.  

During pregnancy, high circulating concentrations of estrogen and progesterone increase prolactin levels by 10- to 20-fold. Estrogen and progesterone inhibit the stimulatory effects of prolactin on milk production. The abrupt drop in estrogen and progesterone levels following delivery allows prolactin—which temporarily remains high—to induce lactation. Other prolactin-releasing stimuli include the nursing stimulus, as well as stress.  



Option Analysis

❌ Prolactin secretion from the posterior pituitary is constantly inhibited by dopamine:
Incorrect: Prolactin is secreted by lactotrophs located in the anterior pituitary and is tonically inhibited by dopamine from the tuberoinfundibular pathway of the hypothalamus.
❌ Metoclopramide inhibits the release of prolactin:
Incorrect: Metoclopramide is a dopamine antagonist and it stimulates the release of prolactin.  
✅ Thyrotropin-releasing hormone can stimulate prolactin release  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Prolactin release from the anterior pituitary stimulates GnRH:
Incorrect: Prolactin release from the anterior pituitary inhibits GnRH synthesis and release. The GnRH inhibition results in decreased luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels from the anterior pituitary.  
❌ Prolactin stimulates its own release by increasing dopamine synthesis  :
Incorrect: Increased prolactin inhibits its own secretion by increasing dopamine synthesis and secretion from the hypothalamus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic because of a recent weight loss of 4.5-kg (9.9-lb) and recurrent fatty stools over the past several months. The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus and gallstones. Laboratory studies show decreased concentrations of pepsinogen, amylase, lipase, insulin, and glucagon. A CT scan shows a mass in the pancreas. Based on this patient's symptoms, which of the following substances might be secreted by this pancreatic tumor?
questions.solution:
Somatostatin is an inhibitory hormone that is normally produced by the D-cells of the pancreas. It inhibits gastric acid, pepsinogen, insulin, glucagon, pancreatic and small intestine fluid release, and also inhibits gallbladder contraction. Somatostatin secretion is induced by amino acids, free fatty acids, glucose, glucagon, and cholinergic and β-adrenergic neurotransmitters. It is inhibited by α-adrenergic neurotransmitters and insulin.

Option Analysis

❌ Cholecystokinin:
Incorrect: Cholecystokinin  is a hormone produced in the duodenum that stimulates pancreatic and gallbladder secretion of enzymes and bile, respectively, to aid in the digestion of fat and protein.  
❌ Gastrin:
Incorrect: Gastrin is produced by the G-cells in the gastric mucosa and stimulates the release of gastric acid from parietal cells.
❌ Intrinsic factor  :
Incorrect: Intrinsic factor is secreted by parietal cells in the stomach. It binds to vitamin B12 to facilitate absorption in the terminal ileum.
❌ Secretin:
Incorrect: Secretin is released by duodenal S-cells. It helps to maintain pH and the digestive environment in the duodenum. It stimulates secretion in the stomach, liver, and pancreas.
✅ Somatostatin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old scientist with a medical history of type II diabetes mellitus and obesity carries out an experiment in which she injects herself with glucose intravenously in the form of 5% dextrose solution. Afterward, she takes a blood sample to measure serum insulin levels. The next day, she orally administers the same amount of glucose and retakes the blood sample. The serum insulin levels were higher this time than in the previous sample. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this discrepancy?

choices.text: History of type II diabetes mellitus
Glucose uptake by other organs when given intravenously

questions.solution:
Glucose is the major regulator of insulin release. However, insulin release is enhanced by incretins, gut hormones secreted from enteroendocrine cells into the blood in response to an oral glucose load. They increase insulin release mainly by augmenting beta (β) cell sensitivity to glucose. The phenomenon is referred to as “the incretin effect”. In the vignette, this effect accounts for the higher insulin levels in response to oral glucose than intravenous glucose.  

There are two types of incretin: glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1) and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP), also known as a gastric inhibitory peptide. GLP-1 is secreted from enteroendocrine L-cells of the small intestine, while GIP is secreted from K-cells of the small intestine. Eventually, GLP-1 is broken down into inactive metabolites by an enzyme called dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP4).  

Based on this phenomenon, two medications have been developed to enhance insulin secretion, lowering blood glucose levels in patients with type II diabetes mellitus. The first is an incretin mimetic (e.g. exenatide, which is an agonist of the GLP-1 receptor), and the other is an incretin enhancer (e.g. sitagliptin, which is a DPP4 inhibitor).  

Option Analysis

❌ History of type II diabetes mellitus  :
Incorrect: Type II diabetes mellitus is associated with insulin resistance. However, the condition does not affect the insulinotropic effects of glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1), which is the cause of higher serum insulin levels in response to oral glucose load in this subject.
❌ Glucose uptake by other organs when given intravenously  :
Incorrect: Glucose uptake is facilitated by glucose transporters (GLUT). Although each GLUT has a different affinity for glucose uptake, it cannot be the reason for the discrepancy in serum insulin levels between oral versus intravenous glucose administration.  
❌ Age-related changes:
Incorrect: Age is not shown to be associated with the degree of insulin release in response to oral versus intravenous glucose load. The incretin effect is a more likely explanation.
❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: Obesity is associated with insulin resistance. However, obesity is not associated with the degree of insulin release in response to oral versus intravenous glucose administration. The incretin effect is a more likely explanation.  
✅ Incretin effect  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: Insulin glargine is added to the medication regimen of a patient with a hemoglobin A1c of 11.2%. Which changes will most likely occur in response to this new medication?
questions.solution:
Insulin is an anabolic peptide hormone that binds to a tyrosine kinase receptor on target tissues (e.g., liver, skeletal muscle, adipose tissue) to regulate the metabolism of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats. Insulin stimulates glucose uptake by increasing the expression of GLUT4 in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue and glucokinase activity in the liver.  

Insulin decreases protein kinase A activity, which leads to increased fructose-2,6-bisphosphate (F-2,6-BP) concentration. Increased F-2,6-BP concentration increases the activity of the glycolytic enzyme phosphofructokinase-1 and decreases the activity of the gluconeogenic enzyme fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase.  

Moreover, insulin increases glycogenesis by activating glycogen synthase.  

Insulin decreases lipolysis in adipose tissue by decreasing the expression of adipocyte triglyceride lipase and increases lipogenesis by increasing the activity of acetyl CoA carboxylase, HMG CoA reductase, and endothelial lipoprotein lipase.  

Finally, insulin promotes amino acid uptake and protein synthesis and decreases ketogenesis.

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Insulin administration would increase glycogenesis and glycolysis. Moreover, insulin would decrease gluconeogenesis and lipolysis.
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the effects of glucagon, which would result in decreased hepatic glycolysis and glycogenesis and increased lipolysis and hepatic gluconeogenesis. Insulin has a different set of effects.
❌ :
Incorrect: Insulin administration would increase glycogenesis and inhibit lipolysis. However, it would lead to an increase, not a decrease, in glycolysis. Moreover, insulin administration would decrease gluconeogenesis and hepatic glucose production.
❌ :
Incorrect: Epinephrine causes an increase in lipolysis, muscle glycolysis, hepatic gluconeogenesis, and a decrease in glycogenesis. Insulin has a different set of effects.

questions.text: A scientist is studying the mechanism of insulin release from pancreatic beta (β) cells. Which of the following is the main trigger for insulin release in the human body?
questions.solution:
Glucose is the major regulator of insulin release. When glucose is absorbed into the bloodstream and reaches the beta islet cells of the pancreas, it is sensed by glucose transporters 2 (GLUT2) on the cell surface. Glucose enters β cells, where it generates ATP via cellular respiration. An increase in ATP closes potassium (K+) channels and depolarizes the cell membrane. Depolarization leads to voltage-gated calcium (Ca2+) channels opening, leading to Ca2+ influx and stimulation of insulin release via exocytosis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Glucose:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fructose:
Incorrect: Fructose is not the main trigger for insulin release in the human body.  
❌ Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1):
Incorrect: Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) is an incretin released from enteroendocrine L-cells in the small intestine in response to an oral glucose load. It increases insulin release mainly by augmenting beta (β) cell sensitivity to glucose. However, GLP-1 is not a direct trigger for insulin release.  
❌ Gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP):
Incorrect: Gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP) is an incretin released from enteroendocrine K-cells in the small intestine in response to an oral glucose load. It increases insulin release mainly by augmenting beta (β) cell sensitivity to glucose and is not a direct trigger for insulin release. 
❌ Sympathetic neural activity   :
Incorrect: Studies have shown that insulin secretion stimulates feeding-induced parasympathetic neural activity in the pancreas. In contrast, stress-induced sympathetic neural activity in the pancreas inhibits insulin secretion.

questions.text: A segment of the thyroid gland is examined under microscopy. In the examination, 2 types of cells are identified: one that is responsible for the production of thyroid hormones, and another type of cell that is responsible for secreting a different type of hormone. The second type of cell is shown in the image below (black arrow). The hormone produced by these cells does which of the following functions?

choices.text: Decreases reabsorption of phosphorus in the distal convoluted tubules.
Decreases absorption of calcium from the intestines
Decreases reabsorption of phosphorus in the proximal convoluted tubules.
Increases absorption of calcium in the distal convoluted tubules

questions.solution:
Calcitonin is a peptide hormone that is produced by the parafollicular cells (C-cells) in the thyroid gland, which make up a tiny minority of the gland. Parafollicular cells are pale-staining cells that are typically situated basally in the epithelium, without direct contact with the follicular lumen. These cells are found between the follicles of the thyroid gland as shown in the image.  

Calcitonin is a hormone that plays a role in the regulation of calcium levels in the blood. When free ionized calcium levels rise in the blood, they stimulate the release of calcitonin from the parafollicular cells. Calcitonin then helps lower the calcium levels (remembered as calcitonin “tones down” calcium) by its actions on the bones (primarily) and the kidneys.


In the bones, calcitonin binds to calcitonin receptors on the osteoclasts, and inhibits bone resorption; this lowers the release of calcium and phosphorus in the blood, and thereby lowers serum calcium levels. The bones are the main site of action of calcitonin.


However, minor actions of calcitonin are on the kidneys, which also helps to lower serum calcium levels. Calcitonin activates its receptors in the distal convoluted tubules, and once activated, they inhibit the principal cells in the tubules from reabsorbing calcium and phosphorus, leading to decreased calcium and phosphorus levels in the blood, and increased excretion of both ions in the urine causing calciuria and phosphaturia.  



Option Analysis

✅ Decreases reabsorption of phosphorus in the distal convoluted tubules.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreases absorption of calcium from the intestines  :
Incorrect: Calcitonin has no effect on calcium absorption from the intestines.
❌ Increases bone resorption  :
Incorrect: Calcitonin decreases bone resorption.  
❌ Decreases reabsorption of phosphorus in the proximal convoluted tubules.:
Incorrect: Calcitonin has no effects on the proximal convoluted tubule as there are no receptors located in that segment of the nephron for it. It decreases the reabsorption of phosphorus and calcium in the distal convoluted tubules.
❌ Increases absorption of calcium in the distal convoluted tubules:
Incorrect: Calcitonin decreases the reabsorption of calcium in the distal convoluted tubules.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia, currently controlled with haloperidol, is concerned about abnormal discharge from both nipples over the past 3 months. The patient describes the fluid as white. On further review of systems, he endorses a diminished sexual drive. It is determined that this patient’s symptoms are secondary to the increased release of a hormone. This hormone is secreted into the circulation at which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of this patient is consistent with hyperprolactinemia, leading to bilateral galactorrhea and decreased libido.  

Prolactin is secreted mainly by lactotroph cells in the anterior pituitary gland. It stimulates milk production in the breast and also inhibits ovulation in females and spermatogenesis in males by inhibiting GnRH synthesis and release. The GnRH inhibition results in decreased luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels from the anterior pituitary. FSH and LH normally induce the development of ovarian follicles and ovulation; this explains why women typically do not ovulate or have menstrual periods while breastfeeding. Excessive amounts of prolactin are associated with decreased libido. The secretion of prolactin is tonically inhibited by dopamine from the tuberoinfundibular pathway of the hypothalamus; this pathway was most likely interrupted by this patient’s medication for schizophrenia, which was likely an antipsychotic, most of which are dopamine antagonists.  

Oxytocin, on the other hand, is synthesized within the neurons in the paraventricular and supraoptic nuclei and is released into the circulation from the axon terminal in the posterior pituitary. Oxytocin acts mainly on mammary ducts to facilitate milk letdown during nursing. It also may help initiate or facilitate labor by stimulating the contraction of the uterine smooth muscle.  

Outside of pregnancy, oxytocin levels are low, but production increases just a bit during an orgasm.  

Option Analysis

✅ A:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ B:
Incorrect: This is the vestigial intermediate lobe of the pituitary gland, which is derived from Rathke's pouch during embryonic development. Although it is not a significant source of secretory products in humans, it can secrete a small amount of melanocyte-stimulating hormone.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: Vasopressin (also known as ADH) and oxytocin are synthesized within the neurons in the paraventricular and supraoptic nuclei and are released into the circulation from the axon terminal in the posterior pituitary. Oxytocin acts mainly on mammary ducts to facilitate milk letdown during nursing. It also may help initiate or facilitate labor by stimulating the contraction of uterine smooth muscle.  
❌ D:
Incorrect: The posterior hypothalamus is involved in the control of sympathetic responses including temperature regulation.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: The mammillary bodies are important for memory recall. This region does not directly secrete hormones.

questions.text: Growth hormone (GH) is a peptide hormone that stimulates growth, cell reproduction, and cell regeneration in humans and other animals. Which of the following is true regarding growth hormone?

choices.text: Its secretion is pulsatile, with highest peak levels occurring at early in the morning
Lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary stimulates the release of growth hormone
It stimulates linear bone growth and muscle growth through IGF-1
It is released constantly in response to growth hormone–releasing hormone
It increases insulin sensitivity by enhancing glucose tolerance

questions.solution:
Growth hormone (GH), also called somatotropin, is secreted by the anterior pituitary gland. It induces protein synthesis and nitrogen retention and also impairs glucose tolerance by antagonizing insulin action. GH also stimulates lipolysis, leading to increased circulating fatty acid levels, reduced omental fat mass, and enhanced lean body mass. GH promotes sodium, potassium, and water retention and elevates serum levels of inorganic phosphate. Linear bone growth occurs as a result of complex hormonal and growth factor actions, including those of IGF-I. GH stimulates epiphyseal prechondrocyte differentiation. These precursor cells produce IGF-I locally, and their proliferation is also responsive to growth factors. It is released in pulses in response to growth hormone–releasing hormone (GHRH), with the highest peak levels occurring at night, generally correlating with sleep onset.  

Option Analysis

❌ Its secretion is pulsatile, with highest peak levels occurring at early in the morning:
Incorrect: GH secretion is pulsatile, with the highest peak levels occurring at night, generally correlating with sleep onset.
❌ Lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary stimulates the release of growth hormone:
Incorrect: Somatotrophs in the anterior pituitary stimulate the release of growth hormones. Lactotrophs are the cells in the anterior pituitary that produce and release the hormone prolactin.  
✅ It stimulates linear bone growth and muscle growth through IGF-1  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ It is released constantly in response to growth hormone–releasing hormone:
Incorrect: Growth hormone is released in pulses in response to growth-hormone–releasing hormone.
❌ It increases insulin sensitivity by enhancing glucose tolerance  :
Incorrect: Growth hormone decreases insulin sensitivity by impairing glucose tolerance.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the ED by his partner after the patient became disoriented, diaphoretic, and tachycardic. The patient is found to have a blood glucose of 40 mg/dL. Which of the following hormonal changes will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: ↑ GHRH → ↑ GH → ↑  IGF-I → decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis
↑ GHRH → ↑ GH → ↓ IGF-I  →  decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis
↑  IGF-I  → ↑ GH → ↑ GHRH → increased glucose uptake and decreased lipolysis
↑ Somatostatin → ↑ GH →  ↑ IGF-I  → decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis
↑ Somatomedin → ↑ GH →  ↑ IGF-I  → decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis

questions.solution:
Growth hormone (GH) acts on a number of target tissues and organs, including bones and muscles, adipose tissue, and the liver. Stimulation of GH production and secretion occurs through hypothalamic neurosecretory nuclei production of growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) in response to stress, hypoglycemia, deep sleep, or during exercise. Positive feedback for GH secretion is also known to occur from a hormone produced in the stomach, called ghrelin, which induces additional food intake. GH acts by binding to specific receptors, located mostly in the liver, and induces intracellular signaling by a phosphorylation cascade involving the JAK/STAT (signal-transducing activators of transcription) pathway. Its predominant action is to stimulate hepatic synthesis and secretion of insulin-like growth factor 1; IGF-1 mediates most of the peripheral actions of GH.  

IGF-1, which is produced by the liver, provides negative feedback to the pituitary and hypothalamus to limit GH and GHRH secretion, respectively. Other sources of negative feedback and GH suppression occur through somatostatin, also called growth hormone-inhibiting hormone (GHIH), which is produced by both the pancreas and the hypothalamus. Somatostatin also directly suppresses GH release by producing somatotropin release-inhibitory factor (SRIF).  



Option Analysis

✅ ↑ GHRH → ↑ GH → ↑  IGF-I → decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ ↑ GHRH → ↑ GH → ↓ IGF-I  →  decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis:
Incorrect: Increased growth hormone stimulates the release of insulin-like growth factor, which decreases glucose uptake in tissue and increases lipolysis.  
❌ ↑  IGF-I  → ↑ GH → ↑ GHRH → increased glucose uptake and decreased lipolysis  :
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia stimulates the release of GHRH from the hypothalamus, which in turn releases the GH from the anterior pituitary. Insulin-like growth factor inhibits the release of GHRH and GH via negative feedback.  
❌ ↑ Somatostatin → ↑ GH →  ↑ IGF-I  → decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis  :
Incorrect: Somatostatin is a GHRH inhibitor and is released in states of hyperglycemia to help maintain blood glucose levels. Hypoglycemia would not stimulate its secretion.
❌ ↑ Somatomedin → ↑ GH →  ↑ IGF-I  → decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis:
Incorrect: Somatomedin is a regulatory molecule secreted by the liver in response to GH acting on target tissues.  Hypoglycemia would not stimulate its secretion.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying the synthesis and secretion of insulin and C-peptide. Which of the following statements is true regarding insulin synthesis?

choices.text: Insulin is synthesized in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum of pancreatic beta cells
C-peptide is packaged with insulin in secretory vesicles
C-peptide is further cleaved into insulin
Insulin is secreted directly from the cytoplasm via endolysosomes
Exogenous insulin use increases insulin and C-peptide levels

questions.solution:
Insulin is synthesized in pancreatic beta cells as preproinsulin, which is guided by a signal peptide into the rough endoplasmic reticulum during translation. The signal peptide is removed, converting preproinsulin to proinsulin. Protein folding and disulfide bond formation occur as proinsulin traverses the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Proinsulin is then transported to the Golgi apparatus, packaged with proteolytic enzymes into insulin secretory granules, and cleaved into mature insulin and C-peptide. C-peptide and insulin are then co-secreted from the pancreatic beta cells in equimolar amounts.  

C-peptide (connecting peptide) connects the alpha and beta chains of proinsulin. It plays a vital role in the correct folding of insulin and the formation of disulfide bridges.  



Option Analysis

❌ Insulin is synthesized in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum of pancreatic beta cells:
Incorrect: Insulin is synthesized in the rough endoplasmic reticulum of pancreatic beta cells.
✅ C-peptide is packaged with insulin in secretory vesicles:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ C-peptide is further cleaved into insulin:
Incorrect: Proinsulin is secreted from the beta cells located within the islets of Langerhans of the endocrine pancreas. Afterward, proinsulin is cleaved into insulin and C-peptide.  
❌ Insulin is secreted directly from the cytoplasm via endolysosomes  :
Incorrect: Insulin is packaged into vesicles by the rough endoplasmic reticulum and then secreted from the beta cells via exocytosis. In contrast, some other proteins, such as interleukin-1, lack a signaling sequence and are hypothesized to be secreted directly from the cytoplasm via endolysosomes.
❌ Exogenous insulin use increases insulin and C-peptide levels:
Incorrect: Insulin and C-peptide are increased during increased endogenous insulin production, such as insulinomas and sulfonylurea use. In contrast, exogenous insulin lacks C-peptide.
